pullrequest.title: Rotate imu sensor frames to match diagram

content.raw: I also just discovered a regression of [gazebo issue 236](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/236) for the ImuSensor while testing this. If you reset the world after N seconds of simulation, it may take N seconds before the ImuSensor's start publishing again. I have a partial fix for which I can submit a pull request.
content.html: I also just discovered a regression of gazebo issue 236 for the ImuSensor while testing this. If you reset the world after N seconds of simulation, it may take N seconds before the ImuSensor's start publishing again. I have a partial fix for which I can submit a pull request.

pullrequest.title: Rotate imu sensor frames to match diagram

content.raw:
Some notes about testing:

In the second test case, make sure to wait until the arm is at equilibrium before looking at the affected value of acceleration.

You can also achieve the same pose using arm teleop: press shift-A until the hand is perpendicular to the starting point, with the thumb pointing towards the ground (so that finger-Y is parallel with gravity).
content.html:
Some notes about testing:

In the second test case, make sure to wait until the arm is at equilibrium before looking at the affected value of acceleration.

You can also achieve the same pose using arm teleop: press shift-A until the hand is perpendicular to the starting point, with the thumb pointing towards the ground (so that finger-Y is parallel with gravity).

pullrequest.title: Rotate imu sensor frames to match diagram

content.raw: I'm following your testing protocol but looking at the diagram, shouldn't be the X and Z values the ones that change on `index3` IMU after applying 11Nm to `wristy`?
content.html: I'm following your testing protocol but looking at the diagram, shouldn't be the X and Z values the ones that change on index3 IMU after applying 11Nm to wristy?

pullrequest.title: Rotate imu sensor frames to match diagram

content.raw:
Steve explained this to me yesterday; perhaps this will help.

![armdown.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/rnoXja/images/2111644534-armdown.png)

If you rotate the arm so that it's in this position, the y-axis of the `index3` IMU is pointing up, directly opposing gravity. The IMU acceleration measures `a-g`, where `a` is the acceleration of the link, and `g` is gravity. So when the hand comes to rest at this position, you should see a y value of roughly positive 9.8, because `a-g=0-(-9.8)=+9.8`.

I was confused about the instruction to put a force on the arm at first, because I immediately though I had to measure acceleration while the force was acting on the wrist to see how the force affected the acceleration. But Steve's test is measuring the direction of gravity when the arm is at rest, and the force is simply a way of getting the hand to the exact position needed. For me, the easiest way to do this was not to pause simulation, but to rotate the arm to that position using arm teleop and then look at topic visualization.
content.html:
Steve explained this to me yesterday; perhaps this will help.

If you rotate the arm so that it's in this position, the y-axis of the index3 IMU is pointing up, directly opposing gravity. The IMU acceleration measures a-g, where a is the acceleration of the link, and g is gravity. So when the hand comes to rest at this position, you should see a y value of roughly positive 9.8, because a-g=0-(-9.8)=+9.8.

I was confused about the instruction to put a force on the arm at first, because I immediately though I had to measure acceleration while the force was acting on the wrist to see how the force affected the acceleration. But Steve's test is measuring the direction of gravity when the arm is at rest, and the force is simply a way of getting the hand to the exact position needed. For me, the easiest way to do this was not to pause simulation, but to rotate the arm to that position using arm teleop and then look at topic visualization.
